awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Laser Sources for Scalable Optical Connectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be in demonstrating a new laser used for the complex computer networks of the high-performance computing (HPC) and data communications industries. HPCs are critical for studying many complex scientific phenomena. Likewise, cloud datacenters represent the backbone of the pervasive connectivity that enables mobile computing, communications, and networking.  Both HPCs and datacenters are increasingly reliant on advanced techniques to link hundreds of thousands of computers.  The proposed project enables new systems with improved performance, efficiency, reliability, and cost.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will focus on optimizing the performance of novel semiconductor quantum dot based multiwavelength laser sources.  Multiwavelength lasers with adequate output power and low noise for commercial applications have long proven challenging due to gain competition between lasing modes and dispersion.  The designs and materials platform developed in this project address these challenges directly. The quantum dot gain material provides stability against the traditional barriers to multiwavelength laser performance. By optimizing material properties and device designs, the gain competition between dot sub-populations and the effects of dispersion will be minimized. This can be used for various integrated circuit chips, including ethernet switches, graphics processing units, and field-programmable gate arrays.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Recent years have shown a rapid rise in demand for highly interconnected computing systems for artificial intelligence and machine learning applications. The application level efficiency of these systems are increasingly bottlenecked by the interconnect performance within the compute clusters. Scaling bandwidth in the wavelength domain via dense wavelength-division multiplexing (DWDM) is the most attractive architecture for simultaneously optimizing bandwidth density while minimizing power, latency, and fiber count of the interconnect system. To enable the practical deployment of DWDM interconnects, a scalable multi-wavelength source is necessary.

Through our NSF SBIR, Quintessent developed high performance multiwavelength lasers with world record output powers and low noise at frequency spacings relevant for dense wavelength division multiplexed optical communications.  We also developed a novel laser design offering a deterministic-by-design number of wavelengths and frequency spacing between these wavelengths. Such a laser is advantageous because it represents a single source of multiple channels of data that can be aligned to standardized communication grids; this provides a cost and reliability advantage over using an array of single wavelength lasers to provide signal for each channel. Competing technologies also generally suffer from efficiency penalties due to generating optical power at unused wavelengths and tend to require precise temperature control to stay aligned to the communications grid.

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2024
Modified by: Alan Y Liu
